content.description: A monatomic ideal gas in a sealed container is taken from state <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to state <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> through intermediate states <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown in the above graph of pressure <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of volume <math alttext="V" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
content.question: The internal energy of the gas in state <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the same as that in which other state?

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
